statsBulletinHeadline.headline1: Comparing the estimates for March to May 2014 with those for December 2013 to February 2014, employment continued to rise and unemployment continued to fall.
statsBulletinHeadline.headline2: There were 30.64 million people in work, 254,000 more than for December 2013 to February 2014 and 929,000 more than a year earlier.
statsBulletinHeadline.headline3: The proportion of people aged from 16 to 64 in work (the employment rate) continued to rise, reaching 73.1% for March to May 2014.
statsBulletinHeadline.title: UK Labour Market, July 2014
statsBulletinHeadline.summary: Labour market statistics (including employment, unemployment and economic inactivity) for the United Kingdom.

datasets.title: Unemployment data collection
datasets.summary: People without a job who have been actively seeking work in the UK

statsBulletins.title: UK Labour Market, July 2014
statsBulletins.summary: Labour market statistics (including employment, unemployment and economic inactivity) for the United Kingdom.

title: Unemployment
summary: The level and rate of UK unemployment is measured by the Labour Force Survey using a definition of unemployment specified by the International Labour Organisation. This defines unemployed people as those without a job who have been actively seeking work in the past four weeks and are available to start work in the next two weeks, or those who are out of work but have found a job and are waiting to start it in the next two weeks. Another measure related to unemployment is the claimant count which measures the number of people claiming Jobseeker's Allowance.

breadcrumb.title: Home
breadcrumb.summary: The UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and the recognised national statistical institute of the UK.

breadcrumb.title: Employment and Labour market
breadcrumb.summary: Labour market statistics tell us about people in and out of work. They cover a wide range of areas, such as: employment, unemployment, participation in the labour force, types of work, earnings, benefits, working patterns and workplace disputes.
